You have heard highlights in the News from Japan... now
for the commentary on Japan and Her People.
Let's take a look now at this fascinating country more
properly called NIHON, (PAUSE) Standing on the bridge of
heaven, the two deities, Izanagi and Izanami, looked down
upon the great ocean. Izanagi dipped his jeweled spear in
the water, and as he lifted it, salt water dropped from
the point and solidified to form the first of the islands
of Japan. Izanagi and Izanami descended to the new land,
married, and began to people heaven and earth. By washing
his left eye, Izanagi produced the Sun Goddess, Amaterasu-
0-mikami. She took over the rule of heaven and passed
earth over to her grandson and his descendants, the Emperors
of Japan. This is the beguiling Shintoist explanation of
origins - right down to the present Emperor. Thus, Japan's
primitive folk religion of nature gods and divine ancestors
is linked from its beginning with the Japanese throne.
The result was SHINTO - the way of the gods - and although
officially abolished after the war, it has seen a new birth.
In fact 30,000 of the original 110,000 shrines are back
in operation.
Let's turn to the land of Fujiyama itself. The first
glimpse of Japan is apt to bo disappointing to the stranger--
the environs of Haneda airport or the Yokohama and Kobe
Docks are less impressive than are most national entrance
gateways. But once the traveller is ashore, and reaches
the Japan that lies beyond the initial drabness, a transformaÂ¬
tion happens. The impact of Japan varies with the individual,
but surprisingly (OFTEN) Japan makes an impression such as
is rarely created elsewhere upon experienced travellers
away from their homelands.
